awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Science Mission Planning, On-orbit Commissioning and Science Activation of the Ionosphere Thermosphere Scanning Photometer for Ion-Neutral Studies (IT-SPINS) Cubesat Mission
awd_abstract_narration:
The Ionosphere Thermosphere Scanning Photometer for Ion-Neutral Studies (IT-SPINS) cubesat will provide novel observations of the composition of Earth’s ionosphere, whose variations influence space weather.  This RAPID award will support significant mission planning tasks to prepare the recently launched satellite, developed under previous NSF awards, to achieve its scientific goals.  Project tasks include identifying optimal science operation modes, commissioning and checking out the satellite upon deployment to its desired orbit, and verifying science operations in order to get the longest possible science mission duration.  These are highly time sensitive tasks, necessitating a RAPID grant award. Undergraduate and graduate students at Montana State University will continue to be integral participants in the project. Additionally, students and a faculty member from the Salish Kootenai College (a tribal land-grant community college) will participate in mission planning and satellite operations, advancing diversity in STEM research and education.

The primary science goal for the IT-SPINS cubesat investigation is to understand the behavior of the topside transition region of the ionosphere, the boundary wherein oxygen ions in the ionosphere interact with low mass constituents of the Earth’s upper atmosphere through charge exchange collisions.  IT-SPINS will profile the oxygen ion distribution in the topside ionosphere from low Earth orbit through remote sensing of 135.6nm emissions from the nighttime ionosphere.  Completed under challenging circumstances during the pandemic, the cubesat was launched in February 2021 and is in an interim parking orbit on the International Space Station, from where it will be deployed in May 2021 to its unique orbit for science investigations.  This RAPID project capitalizes on previous NSF investments by commissioning the IT-SPINS cubesat and performing science operations testing and evaluation.  Owing to the very limited time on orbit prior to reentry of the satellite, it is prudent to perform these tasks before deployment into the desired orbit (for planning and simulations) and as quickly as practical after deployment (for operations evaluations) in order to get the longest possible science mission duration.  The scientific broader impact of the mission will be to improve space weather prediction related to dynamic processes in Earth’s ionosphere by increasing understanding of the drivers for spatial and temporal variations in the mass species distribution in the near-Earth plasma environment.  By integrating students, including tribal college students, into all aspects of the mission planning, satellite testing, and science operations, this project will broaden participation in space physics and space weather.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This RAPID project consists of four primary tasks for preparing the already launched IT-SPINS satellite for its operational scientific mission. This RAPID investigation is motivated by the availability of, and access to, a limited-orbital-lifetime satellite developed under our previous NSF award that left its parking orbit and was deployed into its operational orbit in late June 2021. Devising new alternative operational modes, commissioning the spacecraft as soon as possible following deployment in space and analyzing multiple alternative observing modes before beginning the science mission provides a critically needed opportunity before the satellite's ultimate reentry to maximize scientific return.

These task objectives were to be conducted during somewhat distinct but overlapping phases:

1) Prior to deployment: to create and model mission-related planning of alternative spacecraft operational slew modes for achieving scientific goals of investigating the climatology of the global ionospheric topside transition altitude. Test slew modes in the laboratory using control system simulator.

2) Post deployment early operations and commissioning: to commission and verify the satellite operability upon deployment including exercising the attitude control system to assess its capabilities.

3) Post commissioning science trials: to verify science operations solutions on orbit prior to initiation of the operational mission.

4) Conduct interim operations over a duration of approximately 6-months during which the team would operate the satellite and maintain its health and safety

Sufficient communication with the IT-SPINS satellite allowed the operations team to determine that the avionics hardware including the power system functioned as designed. However, the onboard transceiver purchased from a commercial vendor experienced issues. Attempts to uplink commands were only sporadically successful providing only infrequent opportunities for the satellite to receive and act upon commands sent from the ground.

Sufficient communication with the IT-SPINS satellite allowed the operations team to determine that the avionics hardware including the power system functioned as designed. However, the onboard transceiver purchased from a commercial vendor experienced issues. Attempts to uplink commands were only sporadically successful providing only infrequent opportunities for the satellite to receive and act upon commands sent from the ground.

Initial turn-on of the CTIP Payload indicated healthy payload computer, good motherboard temperature, and a solid RS-422 serial communication path. Subsequent activation included successful increases of the temperature of the heated SrF2 filter and initiation of high voltages to the PMT. The sunshield doors were never opened due to inability to initiate the command through the transceiver.

BROADER IMPACT

Early career engineers and both undergaduate and graduate students were tasked to resolve the communications difficulty and analyze data received from the beacon downlinks and from the infrequently received responses from ground commands. Tasks incuded consultation with both other users of the AstroDev radio, as well as the manufacturer.

Involvement of early career engineers and students in technical problem solving and failure analysis through hands-on experience is incredibly important in building a knowledgable technical workforce.

As a result of this activity a diagnosis of transceiver issues occuring on more than one Astrodev satellite transceiver and thorough characterization of several units have led to a disinclination to use that supplier's radio owing to poor lot-to-lot performance indicating insufficient quality control.

Strong lessons learned include careful evaluation of subsystems being provided by third party commercial suppliers. Analysis of the supplier's long term viability including the supplier's ability to stay in the market in order to provide support to the customer when required is an important consideration in this small satellite subdiscipline.
